channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: After Weeks of Fighting, Russia Occupies Sievierodonetsk
item.description: The takeover of the city came as Russia fired a barrage of missiles at targets across Ukraine. President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia met with the leader of Belarus and promised his ally weapons capable of holding nuclear warheads.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Oslo Shooting Is Being Investigated as Terrorism, Police Say
item.description: The attack, which killed two people and seriously wounded 10 others near a gay club in Oslo, came hours before the city’s Pride parade, which has now been canceled.
item.dc:creator: Henrik Pryser Libell and Mike Ives
item.media:description: Police officers near the scene of a shooting that left two dead on Saturday in Oslo.

item.title: Ukraine’s Coal Miners Struggle While Russia Bombs From Above
item.description: The war has added a new threat to the dangerous lives of miners in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Miners entering an elevator shaft at the start of a six-hour shift this month at a state-run coal mine near the town of Selidove, in eastern Ukraine’s Donbas region.

item.title: In Warsaw Park, Ukraine’s Teen Refugees Hang Out and Hang On
item.description: Some fled to Poland’s capital alone. All feel deeply uneasy about the future. For the young Ukrainians packing into Poland’s capital, a park offers a place where they can try to cope, together.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Warsaw park has become a favorite meeting spot for many of the Ukrainian teenagers who fled to Warsaw after the Russian invasion of their country.

item.title: Germany Ends a Nazi-Era Abortion Law That Criminalized Doctors
item.description: The vote to scrap the law came on the same day that Roe v. Wade was overturned by the U.S. Supreme Court.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: At a clinic where abortion services are provided in Berlin. Lawmakers voted on Friday to end a law that criminalized doctors for publicizing abortion services.

item.title: Bangladesh Floods Cause Death and Destruction in Sylhet
item.description: South Asia is used to downpours, and occasional floods, during monsoon season. But this year’s flooding has been extreme, especially in Bangladesh.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat and Mike Ives
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Syed Mahamudur Rahman/NurPhoto, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Residents sought higher ground as they passed stranded trucks on a flooded street in the Sylhet region of Bangladesh on Wednesday.

item.title: In Afghan Quake: ‘I Did Not Expect to Survive’
item.description: As aid workers and volunteers rushed to help, survivors told harrowing tales of death and destruction.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Safiullah Padshah, Kyle Crichton and Kiana Hayeri
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hawa and her daughter Safia, at the hospital in Sharana, in Afghanistan’s Paktika province, on Thursday. Four of Hawa’s children and 17 other family members perished in the quake.

item.title: Amy Gutman’s Father Fled the Nazis. She’s the New U.S. Ambassador to Germany.
item.description: For Amy Gutmann, a respected democracy scholar, her role as President Biden’s envoy to Germany is not a job, “it’s a mission,” one both professional and personal.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Ingmar Björn Nolting for The New York Times
item.media:description: The U.S. ambassador to Germany, Amy Gutmann, during a visit to Nuremberg, where Hitler once addressed Nazi rallies and her father was an apprentice.

item.title: After Years of Acrimony, China and Australia Cautiously Reach Out
item.description: The arrival of a new government in Canberra has set the stage for ministerial talks and overtures for easing tensions. Plenty still divides the two nations.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: High security walls and a Chinese flag at China’s consulate in Sydney, Australia.

item.title: U.K. Conservatives Lose By-Elections, Adding to Pressure on Boris Johnson
item.description: The double defeat exposed the party’s vulnerabilities and was likely to revive talk of another no-confidence vote against the prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Matthews/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Counting ballots in the Tiverton and Honiton by-election, which was made necessary when the Conservative lawmaker Neil Parish resigned for watching pornography in Parliament.

item.title: How an Abortion Ban Trapped a Tourist on Malta
item.description: Andrea Prudente, an American, developed potentially life-threatening pregnancy complications while on the island. But abortion is illegal there.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Demonstrating against Malta’s ban on abortion, outside Parliament House in the capital, Valletta, on Wednesday.

item.title: South Africa’s Corruption Inquiry Leaves Few of the Nation’s Powerful Unscathed
item.description: The final portion of a three-year investigation reported graft on a massive scale under former President Jacob Zuma, but also found the current president’s actions wanting.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa, right, receives the final investigation report from Chief Justice Raymond Zondo at the government's Union Buildings in Pretoria on Wednesday.

item.title: Russian Elites Show No Sign of Broad Challenge to Putin
item.description: Many business owners and intellectuals fled Russia after the invasion of Ukraine, but others stayed behind, struggling to redefine their lives. Their diverging choices do not add up to a broad challenge to Vladimir Putin’s war.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside the Kremlin in Moscow in February. Russians who stayed after the invasion have taken differing paths in responding to the war.

item.title: How China Is Policing the Future
item.description: Vast surveillance data allows the state to target people whose behavior or characteristics are deemed suspicious by an algorithm, even if they’ve done nothing wrong.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur, Muyi Xiao and John Liu
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China
item.media:description: Surveillance cameras set up in April at a residential compound in Mudanjiang, Heilongjiang Province.

item.title: More than 20 Migrants Die in Effort to Enter Spanish Enclave in Africa
item.description: The deaths occurred during an attempted mass crossing by 2,000 people over border fences into Melilla. Several human rights groups have called for an investigation.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward and Aida Alami
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Migrants climbing the fences separating the Spanish enclave of Melilla from Morocco on Friday. Melilla and Ceuta, another Spanish enclave, have the European Union’s only land borders with Africa.

item.title: Commonwealth’s Fissures Exposed at Week of Meetings
item.description: This year’s summit for the group of nations came as they grappled with the place of the monarchy, and as many were forging connections with powers like China and Russia.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Delegates listened as Britain’s Prince Charles, Prince of Wales, spoke during the opening ceremony of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Kigali, Rwanda, on Friday.

item.title: ‘We Have Nothing’: Afghan Quake Survivors Despair Over Recovery
item.description: With the economy in ruins and aid in short supply, survivors of the earthquake in this remote stretch of eastern Afghanistan wonder what their next move could be.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Safiullah Padshah and Kiana Hayeri

item.title: Russia Unleashes a Missile Barrage, While Inching Ahead in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: Some of the missiles were launched from Belarus, whose leader is meeting Saturday with the Russian president.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Megan Specia and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers firing a self-propelled howitzer on Russian forces in the eastern Donetsk region on Friday.

item.title: ‘Wild Swimming’ in Restricted Beijing Offers Refreshing Break From Rules
item.description: China’s congested and highly regulated capital is not known for either its natural refuges or its rule-bending. But swimming in the city’s lakes and waterways is a cherished, if contested, tradition.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: Swimmers in June in the Liangma River in Beijing. Staircases have been fenced off to prevent people from easily entering the water, but this hasn’t stopped enthusiasts.

item.title: Mayor of Embattled Southern Ukrainian City Urges All Residents to Leave
item.description: The request by the Mykolaiv official was somewhat surprising, given that the city’s combative, never-say-die spirit has become a symbol of Ukrainian resistance.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents waiting for food distribution in Mykolaiv, Ukraine, this week.

item.title: For a Kyiv techno collective, ‘now everything is about politics.’
item.description: “This war has destroyed the statement that art could be outside politics,” the group’s booking and communications manager said.
item.dc:creator: Tom Faber

item.title: The End of Roe
item.description: The Supreme Court’s abortion ruling will transform American life and politics.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anti-abortion advocates celebrate outside the Supreme Court yesterday.

item.title: Russia hits Ukraine with over 40 missiles, including in areas that were recently spared.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers with American-provided weapons in February at a training facility in Ukraine’s west, near Yavoriv, which Russian strikes have targeted on more than one occassion.

item.title: In Southeast Asia, Luxury Hotel Bargains Aren’t Hard to Find
item.description: The region is emerging from Covid isolation only to find a dearth of the Chinese visitors who once flocked there. Some hotels are responding with deals for travelers from the U.S. and elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: Finn-Olaf Jones
item.media:credit: Lauryn Ishak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Marina Bay Sands in Singapore is among the many luxury hotels in Southeast Asia offering enticing deals.

item.title: Belarus’s Leader, ‘Europe’s Last Dictator,’ Burnishes Links to Russia
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia met with President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus on Saturday amid questions over how far Minsk will allow itself to be drawn into the war.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Analysts say Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, an autocrat beholden to Russia, is desperately trying to show his value to President Vladimir V. Putin.

item.title: Occupied Mariupol is suffering deeply, its mayor says.
item.dc:creator: Maham Javaid
item.media:description: Gennady Ivanov, 83, outside a residential building in the southern port city of Mariupol on May 30, two weeks after Russia captured the city’s last military defenders.

item.title: 2 Killed and at Least 19 Wounded in Shooting in Norway’s Capital
item.description: The shooting happened near a popular gay club in downtown Oslo, on the weekend when the city is set to host its Pride parade.
item.dc:creator: Henrik Pryser Libell and Mike Ives
item.media:description: Police officers after the shooting in Oslo, Norway, early Saturday.

item.title: Countries aligned against Russia face growing economic pain, even as Putin proves resilient to sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia giving a speech in Saint Petersburg on June 17.

item.title: U.S.-Led Alliance Face Frustration Over Russia Sanctions
item.description: Vladimir V. Putin is making gains in his war on Ukraine while the United States and its allies struggle with soaring energy prices and inflation.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
item.media:description: Customers buying ice cream at a store near Red Square in Moscow this week.

item.title: Haleh Afshar, Who Fought for Rights of Muslim Women, Dies at 77
item.description: An Iranian-born British scholar and self-described “Muslim feminist,” she joined the House of Lords and advised the British government on women’s issues.
item.dc:creator: Nazila Fathi

item.title: Ukraine Retreats From Sievierodonetsk, as Russia Grinds On
item.description: With the withdrawal from Sievierodonetsk, the fighting shifts to neighboring Lysychansk, the last city in the Luhansk region still under Ukrainian control.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Marc Santora and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers fired an advanced French CAESAR self-propelled howitzer at a Russian target in the Donetsk region on Friday.

item.title: Russian forces move to encircle Lysychansk, starting with southern villages.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
item.media:description: Smoke on Thursday over an oil refinery outside Lysychansk, one of the twin cities in eastern Ukraine where Russian forces have been concentrating attacks in recent weeks.

item.title: With New Threats Looming, Canada Commits Billions to Air Defense
item.description: But it is unclear that giving new capabilities to Norad will be effective against new, superfast missiles.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Norad’s command center is in tunnels under Cheyenne Mountain, Colo.

item.title: Catholic Church Adds to Public Outcry Over Murder of 2 Priests
item.description: The government has failed for years to quell rising violence and the resulting public outcry, but the church’s voice cannot easily be dismissed.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Oscar Lopez
item.media:description: Jesuit priests celebrating Mass on Tuesday at San Ignacio de Loyola church in Mexico City, next to photos of the murdered Jesuit priests Javier Campos and Joaquin Mora.

item.title: E.U. Leaders Prepare In Case Russia Turns Off Gas Supply
item.description: The tapering of gas has forced Germany, Europe’s economic engine, to escalate its energy emergency protocol and urge residents to conserve power. The next step is rationing.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Maham Javaid
item.media:description: A heat and power plant in Berlin on Thursday. Germany may soon have to ration gas, as Russia has shown a willingness to cut off supplies to E.U. buyers.

item.title: Russia Threatens Lithuania Over Kaliningrad Cargo
item.description: Russia has accused Lithuania, a NATO member, of choking off the flow of goods to Kaliningrad, its enclave on the Baltic, as part of sanctions over the war in Ukraine. Lithuania says Russia is lying.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Andrej Vasilenko for The New York Times
item.media:description: The station in Kybartai, Lithuania, from where the railway tracks extend west into Kaliningrad, bringing goods into the Russian exclave.

item.title: Vatican Releases Letters From Jews Pleading for Help During the Holocaust
item.description: Pope Francis has ordered files containing requests for assistance from people throughout Europe, many of them converts to Roman Catholicism, to be made available online.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis, seated right, at a Mass in St. Peter’s Basilica in April. In total, 170 volumes, containing around 2,700 individual appeals, will be published online in an archival series titled “Jews,” the Vatican said.

item.title: Heat Waves Around the World Push People and Nations ‘To the Edge’
item.description: Large, simultaneous heat waves are growing more common. China, America, Europe and India have all been stricken recently, and scientists are starting to understand why certain far-flung places get hit at once.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Emilio Fraile/Europa Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A wildfire raged in the Sierra de la Culebra in Zamora Province in Spain this month.

item.title: The ‘Most Real Richard III There’s Ever Been’
item.description: The Royal Shakespeare Company has cast a disabled actor to play the “deformed, unfinish’d” king for the first time. The choice has been hailed as a landmark moment.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Lauren Fleishman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Arthur Hughes, who plays Richard III in the Royal Shakespeare Company’s new production. His casting “sets the mold for how the industry can change,” he said.

item.title: Ukrainian Insurgents Kill a Kremlin-Backed Politician in Occupied Kherson
item.description: A growing guerrilla movement appears to have been fueled by public anger over worsening economic, security and humanitarian conditions.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: An aerial view of the Russian-occupied city of Kherson last month.

item.title: Relief Efforts Intensify in Afghanistan After Devastating Earthquake
item.description: Aid has been streaming into the rugged regions hit by the quake on Wednesday. Hundreds were killed and many more are missing, with officials saying that they do not expect to find more survivors.
item.dc:creator: Najim Rahim, Cora Engelbrecht and Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: A family setting up tents near where their house had stood in the village of Azor Kalai, Afghanistan, on Thursday. A second temblor hit the region on Friday, killing at least five more people and injuring another 11.

item.title: In Russia’s war over Ukraine, China and India emerge as financiers.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss, Alexandra Stevenson and Emily Schmall
item.media:description: An oil tanker carrying imported crude oil at Qingdao port in China’s eastern Shandong Province last month.

item.title: Commonwealth Meeting in Rwanda Has a Long Agenda. Human Rights Isn’t on It.
item.description: A summit of the organization that was born out of the embers of the British Empire is being held for the first time in the African country, but discussion of the host’s alleged abuses is conspicuously missing.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Dan Kitwood via REUTERS
item.media:description: The opening ceremony of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting on Friday in Kigali, Rwanda.

item.title: Myanmar Junta Sends Aung San Suu Kyi to Solitary Confinement
item.description: The United Nations and human rights advocates criticized the transfer from house arrest, and urged the regime to free her and all other political prisoners.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi taking part in the Martyrs’ Day ceremony in Yangon, Myanmar, in 2019. She was detained in a coup last year.

item.title: How a Supreme Court Ruling and a Senate Bill Could Affect Gun Violence
item.description: The Supreme Court declared that Americans have a broad right to arm themselves in public.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick and Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: The Supreme Court on Thursday.

item.title: Analysis: What the battle for Sievierodonetsk shows about the war.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

item.title: Does Keeping Jurors Unbiased Mean Keeping Everyone Else Quiet?
item.description: A journalist’s comments prompt the delay of a high-profile criminal trial, and everyone gets a reminder in how careful they need to be in discussing ongoing cases.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Brittany Higgins, a former Liberal Party staff member, talking to the news media at the National Press Club in Canberra, Australia, in February.

item.title: Ukraine’s Foreign Minister Sees E.U. Candidacy as a Crucial Step Toward
item.description: “History has been made,” he said of Ukraine’s being accepted as a candidate for E.U. membership.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukraine’s foreign minister, Dmytro Kuleba, at his office in central Kyiv, in north-central Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Ukraine’s E.U. candidacy.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Ukrainian flags flying alongside E.U. flags yesterday in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital.

item.title: Young soccer players rushed out of Ukraine find themselves in a lonely limbo.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Many of the Shakhtar youth academy players, in orange, are entering their fourth month away from their homes and families in Ukraine.

item.title: First Step Toward Ukraine Joining E.U. Signals Solidarity Amid War
item.description: As Russia’s brutal offensive squeezes defenders in eastern Ukraine, Europe’s leaders, in a rebuke to Moscow, made a move they would have rejected before the invasion.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Four soldiers wounded in an artillery strike were dropped off at a bus stop-turned-aid station, where awaiting medics quickly went about stabilizing them on Thursday in Bakhmut, Ukraine.

item.title: Ecuador Roiled by Protests Set Off by Rising Fuel and Food Prices
item.description: The country’s capital has been virtually paralyzed by demonstrators, and the government says it has lost control of a small city in the Amazon to protesters wielding guns, spears and explosives.
item.dc:creator: José María León Cabrera and Megan Janetsky
item.media:description: A protester throwing a tear gas canister at police officers on Wednesday in Quito.

item.title: U.S. Announces $450 Million More in Military Aid for Ukraine
item.description: The latest announcement brings the total amount of military aid from the United States to Ukraine to $6.8 billion since the beginning of the Biden administration.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:description: The United States will send four more truck-mounted rocket launchers, called the M142 HIMARS — for High Mobility Artillery Rocket System — to Ukraine.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: After the Quake
item.description: Afghans search for survivors and China faces twin extreme weather crises.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Lynsey Chutel
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Padshah Gun (30) outside of where used to be his house in Azor Kalai village of Geyun district. From 19 members of his family, 16 survived the earthquake.

item.title: Eurovision Defends Not Allowing Ukraine to Host 2023 Contest
item.description: Eurovision officials cited the need to guarantee the security of all those involved in the contest, robbing Ukraine, this year’s winner, of the chance to be an international showcase.
item.dc:creator: Maham Javaid and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The frontman of Kalush Orchestra, Oleh Psiuk, center, signed an open letter to Eurovision organizers demanding the reversal of their decision to not hold the 2023 edition of the contest in Ukraine.

item.title: Origin of the Monkeypox Outbreak Becomes Clearer to Scientists
item.description: Even as cases rise, genetic analysis suggests that the virus has been silently circulating in people since 2018.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: People wait in line at a monkeypox vaccination clinic in Montreal, in June.

item.title: When, Exactly, Did Mount Vesuvius Erupt?
item.description: From tracing ashes to Greece to analyzing autumnal fruit found in Pompeii, a new study places the eruption in October, not August.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Roberto Salomone for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Pompeii archeological site, in February.

item.title: Austria Quietly Discards Covid-19 Vaccine Mandate that It Never Enforced
item.description: The mandate threatened fines for adults who chose not to be vaccinated, but the government held off enforcement after a panel determined that the Omicron variant was less of a threat than Delta.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Workers processing a shipment of coronavirus vaccines in Salzburg, Austria, in January.

item.title: Pope Francis Will Visit Canada for Apology Despite Health Issues
item.description: Francis plans to deliver a long-sought apology to Indigenous people for the church’s role in a residential school system where abuse was rife.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Pope Francis at the Vatican on Wednesday. Knee problems had caused the postponement of an African trip this month.

item.title: Iran Dismisses Revolutionary Guards’ Powerful Intelligence Chief
item.description: Hossein Taeb, a top official in the force, was transferred to a lower ranking job amid an escalation in Israel’s shadow war with Iran.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Hamed Malekpour/Tasnim News, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Hossein Taeb, a Shiite cleric and head of the intelligence for the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, at a meeting in the capital Tehran in 2018.

item.title: In Remote Afghanistan, Scenes From a Deadly Earthquake
item.description: Officials said hopes of finding additional survivors were fading as they worked to bring aid to the injured in Paktika Province.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
